messageBody:
If testing private methods is what you´re really after I would consider:
a) as already mentioned by others, see if there is some way you can
structure your code so that you can implicitly test whats private with
little effort. As has already been suggested your *Helper may want to
have different names, some may want to be merged, some broken up. And
according to my taste stop being static and then injected to the class
you want to test.

A lot of good stuff can be found here:
http://www.objectmentor.com/resources/publishedArticles.html
(click on by topic | design)

I would start looking at the single responsibility principle. That is
in my experience the principle that had the biggest impact on my
unit-testing (together with the depenency inversion principle).

b) consider making them package-private or default if you prefer to
call it that (remove the private, protected, public modifier
entirely). This is just above private, these methods are only
accessible by other classes in the same package. Not even subclasses
can access them if they are in a different package (there is a common
misunderstanding that default less restricted than protected, it's
really the other way around.

c) perform securitymanager stunts to acces the actual private methods.
I would consider this a bit paranoid.

I look at both b) and c) as workarounds. Sometimes we need workarounds
until we figure out how everything should fit.

Of course, if you are comfortable with the helper style, by all means
continue with that. From where I'm standing it looks like it is the
design part of TDD that wants to be listened to. I am standing quite
far away though so I may be wrong.

/J
